comment.author: 14142328@N04
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Radnorshire, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 14142328@N04
comment._content:
Thanks for all of the additions.

Fantastic to see the area in a bygone era.

comment.realname: Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru  / The National Library of Wales
comment.author: 37199428@N06
comment._content:
Hi,
I'm glad that you like our images. The John Thomas collection contains photographs of landscapes, individuals and groups  of people from across Wales and I'm glad that you have found these images suitable to add to your group.

comment.author: 14142328@N04
comment._content: You're welcome.  I love old photos, seeing how people used to dress, how places used to look or, in the case of this particular shot it raises the question - do people still collect wimberries.  As a 'townie', I will wait for someone else to answer that.

comment.realname: Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru  / The National Library of Wales
comment.author: 37199428@N06
comment._content: I'm sure that they do. When I was growing up in Clocaenog, Denbighshire, we used to collect Whimberries (or 'Llus' as we'd call them in Welsh) on high lands towards the end of the summer.

comment.author: 87667117@N00
comment._content: my grandmother used to pick those during ww1  they were used  to dye sailors uniforms she lived in talgarth

comment.author: 14142328@N04
comment._content: I love hearing things about the past like this.  Can you imagine collecting berries today to dye clothes.  I must look out for these as I have never seen or tasted them.
